message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells. Ischemic necrosis of intestinal mucosa may cause necrotizing enterocolitis. Incomplete coiling of the intestine may cause intestinal malrotation. Mutation in the CFTR gene may cause cystic fibrosis, which does not present with the same symptoms as this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells, leading to absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel and resulting in functional obstruction. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa would be unlikely in a newborn without other risk factors. Incomplete coiling of the intestine can lead to malrotation, which can also cause bowel obstruction, but would not cause absence of ganglion cells. Mutation in the CFTR gene can cause cystic fibrosis, but does not typically present with functional bowel obstruction in the newborn period.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is caused by an impaired migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development. This can lead to a narrowed segment of colon and a dilation proximal to it. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa and incomplete coiling of the intestine are not associated with these findings. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which is not relevant to this case.

We refer to the textbook "Pathologic Basis of Veterinary Disease" which explains that impaired migration of neural crest cells leads to Hirschsprung's disease, which causes a functional obstruction in the colon. This results in the dilated colon proximal to the narrowed segment, leading to the symptoms described in this case. The other options do not fit with the presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells in utero. This results in a lack of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon, leading to colonic distension and functional obstruction. Ischemic necrosis and incomplete coiling of the intestine are not associated with these findings, and a mutation in the CFTR gene would suggest cystic fibrosis, which is not the underlying cause of these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa would not present with bilious vomiting and dilated colon. Incomplete coiling of the intestine is a rare congenital anomaly that would not cause these findings. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which does not typically present with these symptoms in a newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa is not supported by the clinical findings. Incomplete coiling of the intestine and mutation in the CFTR gene are not known causes of Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest the newborn has Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells. Ischemic necrosis of intestinal mucosa is a complication of volvulus or intussusception. Incomplete coiling of the intestine is seen in malrotation with midgut volvulus. Mutation in the CFTR gene is seen in cystic fibrosis which can present with meconium ileus but is not the most likely cause in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa and incomplete coiling of the intestine are not associated with these findings, and mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, not Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is caused by impaired migration of neural crest cells. Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa and incomplete coiling of the intestine are not associated with the symptoms described. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis and not Hirschsprung's disease.
